newsitem.title: INDIA: Exports now less attractive - India Arvind.
newsitem.headline: Exports now less attractive - India Arvind.

text.p: Exports are becoming less attractive to Indian companies due to an overvalued rupee, among other reasons, a top official of textile major Arvind Mills said on Thursday.
"Exports are becoming less attractive," Sanjay Dalal, general manager (finance), told Reuters.
Arvind Mills is India's largest and the world's fifth largest manufacturer of denim fabrics.
The company's exports exceeded $110 million in the year ended March 31, 1997.
Dalal said a 10 percent fall in India's merchandise exports in April 1997 compared with the same month in 1996 was the outcome of several factors.
"An overvalued rupee is an important factor," Dalal said. Other factors were infrastructure bottlenecks and a truckers' strike in April which held up export consignments.
The Indian rupee has been steady at 35.75/85 against the dollar ever since mid-1996 despite rising cost of production of Indian firms and the dollar's rise against major currencies.
"The fall in exports during April is the first sign the overvalued rupee is beginning to hurt exports," said a foreign exchange dealer at a European bank in Bombay.
Infrastructure was another major constraint, Dalal said.
"Productivity gains which will have to take place over a period of time are not happening because of infrastructure bottlenecks," he said.
Dalal said his own company was not facing any deceleration in exports. "Our volumes won't be affected," he said.
Analysts agreed with the company's assessment.
"We expect them to post higher exports than last year in value terms," V. Ramanan, analyst at Peregrine Capital, said.
He said a reduction in cotton prices this year would help Arvind Mills.
